Mrs. Thoeun C., 50 (shown in the photo), and her husband, Mr. Neang Chuy, 46, live on an island in the Mekong River about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh City. They have been married since 1980 and have six children: one daughter who is a garment factory worker and five sons. One of them is married and lives outside the family home, two attend school and the other two stay at home.   
Thoeun has been a silk weaver since she was 18 years old, a skill she learned from her mother. Mr. Neang Chuy has been a fisherman since he was 20 years old. He fishes from the lake near his house and sells in the local market. 
Thoeun is requesting a loan in the amount of $150 to purchase silk materials for her weaving business.

loans.use: To purchase silk materials for her weaving business.

loans.name: Usaphea

texts.en: Mrs. Usaphea U., 40 and her husband, a doctor, have one son and one daughter, both of whom attend school. The family lives in a small village about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia. Usaphea, who has been selling desserts, meat balls and boiled eggs in Phnom Penh for ten years, is requesting a loan of 500 USD to purchase a motorbike for her children to drive to school.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike for her children to drive to school.

loans.name: Srey

texts.en: Mrs. Srey P., 40, and her husband, Mr. Pun Phoeun, a 42-year-old fisherman, have been married since 1990. They live in a suburb of Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia with their daughter, who attends school. Srey grows vegetables on her farmland in the village and is requesting her first loan of $700 to purchase a motorbike for commuting.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike for commuting.

loans.name: Radella

texts.en:
Radella S., a 55-year old married woman who lives in Habitat IV, Brgy Bajumpandan Dumaguete City, Negros Oriental, earns her living by selling vegetables and spices and running a general store. Her husband Apolinar is 59 years old and works as a security guard. They have six children between 14 and 29 years of age, five of whom currently go to school, while the oldest already has a family.

Redalla joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2004 in the hope that she would be able to help her husband improve the quality of life of their family. With the help of her loans from NWTF-PD she has been able to increase their family income by engaging in a general store business and by selling vegetables and spices. Now she earns an average monthly income of Php 15,000 from her business activities.

Redalla is a member in good standing. Her previous loan of Php 15,000 was used to fund operations for her vegetable and spice business and her general store, and it had a positive impact on both the business and the family’s living conditions. Now she is requesting her 11th loan in the amount of Php 13,000, which she intends to use for both her businesses. Redalla is working hard to achieve her dreams and aspirations for her family, which are to provide them with a brighter future and a more comfortable life.

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: Additional working capital

loans.name: Sam-Oeun

texts.en: Mrs. Sam-oeun Khloeng, a widow with two sons and three daughters, lives on an Island in the Mekong River about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh City.  She has just started a business selling finished silk fabric, buying silk products from the weavers in her village and transporting then to sell in other provinces.  Previously, Sam-oeun was a silk weaver. She is  now requesting a loan of $900 to purchase finished silk fabrics for resale.

loans.use: To purchase silk fabrics for resale.

loans.name: Liheng

texts.en:
Mr. Liheng H., 28 and his wife, Mrs. Sokkhai In, 25, were married in 2005 and have a son and daughter, one attending school while the other one stays at home. They live along National Road Number Six about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh City.

Liheng and his wife have been selling fish for one year, purchasing their product from Prek Phnao market and transporting it to sell at a market located in Phnom Penh. The couple hopes to expand their business to generate additional income, so Liheng is asking for his first loan of $500 for that purpose.

loans.use: To expand his business.

loans.name: Navuth

texts.en:
Mrs. Navuth M. and her husband Mr. Heng Hai (pictured together) live along the Tonle Basac River, a tributary of the nearby Mekong, about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh City. They have been married since 1989 and have four children, three sons and one daughter. 

Mrs. Navuth M. sells vegetables and fruits in a Phnom Penh market. Her husband is a chef. He cooks for wedding ceremonies and other ceremonies in his village and sometimes in Phnom Penh. 

Under her wooden house is open airspace, so it’s difficult for her to keep the elements out. She is requesting a loan of $1,000 to build a brick room under her wooden house.

loans.use: To build a brick room under her wooden house

loans.name: Choem

texts.en: Mrs. Choem Y. lives in Pratheat village in Kandal province and she is 61 years old. She is a farmer who owns a small piece of land to cultivate rice  not to sell but to support her family and she sells ice cream door-to-door. Now she has a problem because her motorbike is too old to use. So to improve her business, Mrs. Choem Y. is requesting a loan to buy a new motorbike to sell ice cream. She is a widow with a child who is a seamstress in a garment factory.

loans.use: To buy a new motorbike to sell ice cream

loans.name: Alma

texts.en:
Alma M. is a 57-year-old woman living in Brgy. Libertad, Escalante City, Negros Occidental.  She is married and has two school-aged children.  To make a living, Alma owns & operates a sari sari or general store selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap, toothpaste and other basic commodities in the local community.  Alma has been engaged in this business for over 15 years and earns approximately 20,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2005, Alma joined NWTF to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities.  Alma has successfully repaid a previous loan of 21,000 PHP from NWTF. Alma is now requesting a new loan of 22,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell.  The loan will be the ninth loan taken out by Alma from NWTF.  Alma plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees for her children.

About NWTF:
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Sreang

texts.en: Mrs. Sreang H. lives in Trapeang Chrey village in Kandal province. She was born in 1955. She and her husband, Mr. Sung Nhiem, are telephone sellers in the local market. Since her business is going well, she wants to expand it. So to improve their business, Mrs. Sreang H. is applying for a loan to buy more phones to resell. Through this activity, the couple supports a child who is helping them to sell phones too. Her husband appears in the photo with her.

loans.use: To buy more phones to resell

loans.name: Alice

texts.en:
Alice W. is a 35-year-old lady trading in baby clothing and ladies clothes. She has been in this business for the last 10 years. Her business is located within Nairobi, along a busy road. Her main customers include local residents, visitors and tourists. She has one employee and two school-going children.

She had previously borrowed 20,000 Kenyan shillings and successfully repaid it. She is now borrowing KES 40,000 to increase her stock of baby clothes. Her main business challenge is the harassment from the local authorities and competition from an open-air market within the neighborhood. She sees herself in five years time as a prominent business lady employing people in her company.

loans.use: To purchase more stock to address increasing demand as a result of a baby boom

loans.name: Freecel

texts.en:
Freecel Q., 33 years old, is a married woman who supports her family by selling frozen food products and mineral water. She lives in GK Brgy Villareal Bayawan City, Negros Oriental with her husband and their three children who are between 7-13 years old.

She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2008 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her frozen food products and mineral water businesses, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 6,000.

Freecel is now borrowing PHP 15,000 so that she can continue her frozen food products and mineral water businesses. This will be her fifth cycle loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 9,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Freecel aspires to elevate her family’s living conditions and ensure their future wellbeing by following the “Dungganon” way.  

About NWTF:
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: As additional working capital

loans.name: Pheap

texts.en: In Trapaing Chhrey village in Kandal province lives a person known as Mrs. Pheap C.. She is 32 years old. She and her husband, Mr. Toem Leang Se, are farmers who own a plot of land to cultivate rice to sell to support their family. Although they try to work hard, they can't earn enough income. So to improve their family living conditions, Mrs. Pheap C. is seeking a loan to start a new business by building a store to sell desserts in the local village. She is the mother of four children. Two of the children attend the local public school, and the others are too young to work or study. Her husband is in the photo with her.

loans.use: To build a store to sell desserts

loans.name: Chinheng

texts.en: Mr. Chinheng M. is a villager in Kbal Chrouy village in Kandal province. He was born in 1955. He is a farmer who owns more than a one-hectare plot of land to cultivate rice to support his family. His wife, Mrs. Cheav Hor Khuy, is a rice and coffee seller in the local village. They try to work hard with their careers, but they can't earn enough income. So to improve their family living conditions, Mr. Chinheng M. is seeking a loan to buy some piglets and pig food to start a new business breeding pigs. He is the father of five children. One of the children is a fruit seller, one is a motorbike taxi driver,  one is a seamstress in a garment factory, and the others are attending the local public school. His wife is in the photo with him.

loans.use: To buy some piglets and pig food

loans.name: Derick

texts.en:
Derick is 24 years old and sells clothing (dresses, jeans, trousers, pullovers) primarily for youth (school-going children) and other local customers. His shop is in a busy market center and he manages it himself. Prior to starting this business, Derick was in school. Outside of this business, Derick's family grows vegetables and maize.

Derick plans to use the loan of 40,000 KES to purchase additional clothing inventory and supplies for his shop (dresses, jeans, trousers, bags, and boxes for school-aged children). Derick has successfully repaid one previous loan of 20,000 KES.

He hopes one day to purchase a car for personal use and a plot of land so that he can build a home. In 5 years, Derick hopes to be a wholesaler of new clothing in his town. He also hopes to open up many shops in the region and, not only specialize in new clothes, but also open a boutique. He describes himself as hard-working, strict, and generous.

loans.use: To purchase dresses, trousers, and jeans to sell for school-age children.

loans.name: Thaen

texts.en: Mr. Thaen K. is a villager in Chheu Teal village in Kandal province. He is 42 years old. He is a farmer who owns a plot of land to grow vegetables to sell to support his family. His problem is that his field has infertile soil and it has a lot of insects. So to improve production, Mr. Thaen K. is applying for a loan to buy fertilizer and pesticide. His wife, Mrs. Thara Soun, is a farming laborer. He is the father of four children. One of his children is a soldier, two are seamstresses in a garment factory, and the other is studying in the local public school. His wife is in the photo with him.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and pesticide

loans.name: Matilde

texts.en:
Matilde F.,  47, is making sure that her family has enough provisions for their daily needs. Married to Cezar F., a fish vendor, they are blessed with three children. She makes sure that she helps her husband earn so that their family can have a better life. She has been managing her own variety store and food vending business for several years.

Matilde has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than two years now. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she was able to borrow six times in CCT’s Cooperative. She is consistent in paying her dues because she used the money she borrowed to buy added inventory for her store. Her business allows her earn a profit of PHP 4,400 per month.  

To ensure the success of her business, she would like to apply for a PHP 14,000 loan. This amount will be used as a source of added capital to her expanding business; She will be buying food ingredients for her food vending business.

She dreams that her business will continue to grow so that their standard of living will improve as well. 

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To purchase food ingredients for her food vending business.

loans.name: Arzoo Milad Group

texts.en: This is M. Milad, son of A. Z., a young boy who is 28 years old, single, and the leader of Arzoo Milad group. He lives with his whole family of 8 members, including his father and mother, in Kabul, Afghanistan. He is a very honest and hard working boy. He has a metal shop. He has been involved in this business for more than 6 years. He has requested a loan to buy more iron for his shop. He is happy that, through this process, he can solve his problems.

loans.use: He wants to buy more iron for his shop.

loans.name: Rosita

texts.en:
Rosita A., 45, is making sure that her family has enough provisions for their daily needs. She has been managing her own variety store for several years.

Rosita has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than three years now. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she was able to borrow ten times in CCT’s Cooperative. She is consistent in paying her dues because she used the money she borrows to buy inventory for her variety store. Her business allows her to earn a profit of PHP 4,300 per month.  

Now with your help, she would like to apply for a PHP 18,000 loan. This amount will be used as a source of added capital to her expanding business by buying added inventory for her store.

She dreams that her business will earn more so that she can send her children to school until they graduate from college. 


* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: Towards buying added inventory for her store.

loans.name: Catherine

texts.en:
Catherine C. is from the town of Talibon. She is 26 years old. Catherine is married and has a 2-year-old child. To make a living, Catherine owns & operates a general store where she sells rice and daily use products such as shampoo, soap & toothpaste in the local community. Catherine has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 30000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Catherine joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Catherine has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI. Catherine is requesting a new loan of 25000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the fifth loan taken out by Catherine from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to buy her own vehicle and to save up for her child's education. 

About CEVI:

Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years. Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines.  In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring. CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but additionally savings, insurance, and training which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell.

loans.name: Julieannie

texts.en:
Juliannie T., 27, is making sure that her family has enough provisions for their daily needs. Married to Mark Vargas, a seaman, they are blessed with two children. She makes sure that she helps her husband earn income so that their family can have a better life.  She has been managing her own variety store for several years.

Juliannie has been a regular member of the Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than a year now. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with previous loans, she has been able to borrow from CCT’s Cooperative three times. She is consistent in paying her dues because she uses the money she borrows to buy added stock for her business, which earns a profit of PHP 4,000 per month.  

Now with your help, she would like to apply for a PHP 8,000 loan. This amount will be used to buy more stock for her expanding business. Juliannie dreams that her business will continue to grow to support her family's needs. 

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to buy more stock for her store

loans.name: Rath

texts.en: Mrs. Rath C. is a villager in Tuek Khleang village in Kandal province. She was born in 1975. She is a farmer who owns a plot of land to grow corn to sell to support her family. Her problem is that her field has infertile soil. So to improve production, Mrs. Rath C. is seeking a loan to buy fertilizer. Her husband, Mr. Soa Khut, is a construction worker and she has five children. One of her children is a rice seller and the others are attending the local public school.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer

loans.name: Phem

texts.en: Phem L. is 59 years old and married. To help provide for her family's needs, Phem L. sells a few grocery items out of her home. She has been in this business for years and earns approximately $2.50 per day. To help contribute to the family, her husband works as a wood builder in the village. This couple has been married for years and they have six children: five are married and have already moved into their own homes and one is single. Phem L. hopes to enlarge her business and is applying for a loan to be used to accumulate a larger number of necessary grocery items to sell.

loans.use: to accumulate a larger number of necessary grocery items to sell

loans.name: Sok's Group

texts.en: This group loan has two people who live in Sampan village in Kandal province. Mrs. Sok C. is the group leader, selected by all the members. Each member will use the loan for different purposes to improve their businesses in the future. She and her husband, Mr. Hai Phan, are farmers who own a small piece of land to grow rice and fruit to sell to support their family. Their problem is that their field ready to farm. So to improve production, Mrs. Sok C. is asking for a loan to buy sugar cane to grow. With the rest of the loan, she wants to buy fertilizer and pesticide. She is the mother of nine children. Six of the children are seamstresses in the garment factory and the others are farmers.

loans.use: To buy sugar cane to grow

loans.name: Francis

texts.en: Francis, a single man who operates a retail shop, has been selling maize, cereals and maize flour for four years, and also does commercial farming. Previously, he sold kerosene to earn a living.  Francis joined Faulu Kenya under a group called Shalom 6th and has learned how to save his money and manage his business.  He has also benefited from membership because his group members have guaranteed him a loan of Kes. 20,000 from Faulu Kenya.  Francis plans to use this loan to buy cereals and rice and to pay rent for his shop.  He hopes to expand his business into a wholesale operation in the future.

loans.use: To buy cereals and rice and to pay rent for his business premise

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Antony

texts.en:
Antony is a 27-year-old married man. He sells electronics to earn a living. In addition, he provides "boda boda" (motorbike) transport and is employed in a pharmacy. He strives to put a balance between his businesses and employment. For this reason, he has employed one person to help him in his electronic shop.  

He is a member of the Githunguri Hope group in Faulu Kenya, a Kiva partner.  Being in this group, he can easily access loans from Faulu Kenya because the group members guarantee for each other to get loans. He has requested a loan of 20,000 Kenyan shillings to buy more electronics. He hopes to grow his business so that he may be financially stable.

loans.use: To buy electronics for sale

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Leslie

texts.en: Leslie C. is from the town of Talibon. She is 38 years old. Leslie is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Leslie runs a small sari-sari (variety) store and grows and sells seaweed. Leslie has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 15,000 Philippine pesos a month for these activities. In 2006, Leslie joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Leslie has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Leslie is requesting a new loan of 25,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional inventory for her store and to expand her seaweed business. This will be the ninth loan taken out by Leslie from CEVI, a Kiva partner. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of her children. About CEVI Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over recent years. Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines. In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring. CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but also offers savings, insurance and training provided through regular cluster group meetings. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: Additional store inventory

loans.name: Tha

texts.en:
Mrs. Tha T., 38, owns a medium wooden house and a grocery shop, where she sells many items, including cooking ingredients, sweets and soft drinks. (Mrs. Tha T. was busy when the photo was taken so her husband is shown instead.) Tha T. sells her inventory to people who are also her nearby neighbors. 

She has been running a grocery business for a long time and earns an average of $4.40 a day. To ensure the entire family has financial stability, her husband owns a machine that he uses to supply electricity for client’s batteries for a fee. This couple now lives with two children who are going to school or to work. Tha T. is taking out her loan to increase her inventory and to buy piglets for a stall she built.

loans.use: To increase her inventory and to buy piglets

loans.name: David

texts.en:
David is a married man with six children. He has been doing carpentry for 20 years, manufacturing and selling beds, dining sets, coffee tables, etc. He joined Faulu Kenya, a Kiva partner, with a group of entrepreneurs. With the group, he can easily access a loan from Faulu Kenya since the group members guarantee each other's loans.  

He has requested a loan of 20,000 Kenyan shillings to buy timber, frames, paint, glue, nails, bolts and sand paper. He hopes to expand his business and employ more people.

loans.use: To buy timber, frames, paint, glue, nails, bolts and sand paper

loans.name: Robelyn

texts.en: Robelyn A. is from the town of Talibon. She is 31 years old. Robelyn is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Robelyn operates a fishing business. She makes her own "panggal," a fishing basket made of rattan. The main source of income for her business comes from catching and selling fish at the market. Robelyn has been engaged in her business for over a year and earns approximately 8,000 Philippine pesos a month for these activities. In 2008, Robelyn joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Robelyn has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Robelyn is requesting a new loan of 6,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase fishing equipment including rattan, hooks and nets. This will be the fourth loan taken out by Robelyn from CEVI, a Kiva partner. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to make improvements to her house. About CEVI Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over recent years. Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines. In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring. CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but also offers savings, insurance and training provided through regular cluster group meetings. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase fishing equipment, including hooks and nets

loans.name: Narantsetseg

texts.en: Narantsetseg is 39 years old. She is a widow who lives with son in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. She and her family live together in a rental house. Her son, Orgil, is 16 years old and he attends the local secondary school. She operates her underwear sales business at Sunday Plaza. Narantsetseg started her business in 2009 and made quick progress. Narantsetseg is a very hardworking person. However, in 2006, her husband passed away and she was left to raise her son. At that time, it was hard for her to continue her work, but she has since worked diligently to grow her business to its current successful position. She said, “As a mother, I would like to be financially available to provide a good education and other necessary expenses for my son until he grow up and also I would like to expand my business and to purchase my own apartment for my family in the future." She is requesting a loan to increase her working capital.

loans.use: To increase her working capital

loans.name: Suon

texts.en:
H. is 41 years old and a married man. His wife, who appears in the photo, is a local cultivator. This couple have five children all of whom attend the public local school. H. is currently able to generate a great income by selling chopped wood. He first purchases firewood at a reasonable price from people who live near the forest, then he sells the wood at retail prices thus gaining a profit.

Typically, H. hires his neighbor’s animal to transport the firewood to be sold. To help reduce his costs, he is applying for a loan to purchase a pair of oxen which he will use to pick up and deliver the chopped wood.

loans.use: To purchase a pair of oxen to pick up and deliver firewood

loans.name: Semu

texts.en: K. Semu is 52 years old: she is married with seven children, two of whom attend school. She is a hard worker involved in agriculture. She has a banana plantation where she has been a farmer for more than 20 years. She is using the loan to improve her banana plantation's productivity by buying fertilizers and other things. Her dream is to really improve upon her family’s standard of living.

loans.use: To improve her banana plantation's productivity by buying fertilizers, etc.

loans.name: Kioko

texts.en:
Kioko is a 50-year-old man who is married with four school-going children aged between 8 and 18 years. He has been running a cafeteria business for 22 years and employs one person. He is a hard-working and determined man who strives to support his family and provide quality education for his children.

Kioko is a member of the Urafiki Development self-help group under Faulu Kenya. Through being a member of this group, he has benefited because the group members previously guaranteed him a loan. He wants to buy wheat flour, cooking fat and maize flour for cooking in his cafeteria hence he has requested a loan of 20,000 KES from Faulu Kenya.

loans.use: To buy wheat flour, cooking fat and maize flour

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Jane Kaundar

texts.en: N. Jane Kaundar is a hard-working businesswoman aged 38. She is married with four children all of whom go to school, two at primary level and two at secondary level. She owns a beauty salon in Ntungamo Town Council, Cell 1, Parkward and Ntungamo District. She has spent 12 years in business. She is investing more in her salon by buying materials (hair rollers, towels, relaxers, hair gel, oil, spray and so forth) to use. She wants to expand her salon into a big beauty center and moreso she dreams of owning a big building in Ntungamo town.

loans.use: To buy materials (hair rollers, towels, relaxers, hair gel, oil, spray, etc.) to use in her salon

loans.name: Claire Eileen

texts.en:
Claire Eileen B. is from the town of Talibon. She is 27 years old, married with three school-aged children. To make a living, Claire Eileen owns and operates a fishing business. She makes "panggals", fishing baskets which her husband uses to catch fish. She also sells these baskets to other fishermen. She sells her husband's catch in the market. She has been engaged in this business for over two years now.

In 2008, Claire Eileen joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Claire Eileen is requesting a new loan of 12000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be the third loan which she has taken out from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income. 

About CEVI:

Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over recent years. Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines. In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring. CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but additionally savings, insurance and training which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Yusuf

texts.ru: Муродалиев Юсуф проживает в городе Куляб. Возраст, 41 год. Женат, имеет 4 детей. Образование средне - специальное "Водитель". Работает по профессии в УЖД (управлении железной дороги). Кроме того более 15 лет занимается животноводством. Он в основном откармливает и продает скот. В этом ему помогает жена. Кредит берет для закупа крупно - рогатого скота.
texts.en:
Yusuf M. lives in the town of Kulob. He is 41 years old. He is married and has four children. He has specialized secondary education in driving (vehicle operator). He works in the rail road administration. He also does animal husbandry for more than fifteen years. He mainly feeds and sells cattle. His wife also helps him with this. He is asking for a loan to buy large cattle.

Translated from Russian by Elena Bortnikoff, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy large cattle

loans.name: Sin

texts.en: Mr. Sin S. is a 37-year-old fish catcher and the father of two school-aged children. Every day in the early morning, Mr. Sin S. and his wife fish in and around the river and they quickly bring the fish they have caught to sell at the market. He needs more tools to use for fishing but he doesn’t have the money yet to fulfill his requirement. Therefore, Mr. Sin S. decided to request a loan of $1000 which he will use to purchase many sets of accessories for him to use when fishing on the river.

loans.use: To purchase many sets of fishing accessories

loans.name: Valeriana

texts.en:
Valeriana T. is from the town of Talibon. She is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Valeriana owns and operates a general store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling both food and daily use products in the local community. Valeriana has been engaged in her business for over 10 years already.

In 2008, Valeriana joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI. Valeriana is requesting a new loan of 12000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support her family. 

About CEVI:

Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over recent years.  Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines.  In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring.  CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but additionally savings, insurance and training which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Bibi Saltanat Group

texts.en:
Humayoon is the son of S. W. and the leader of the Bibi Saltanat group. He lives in District 8th, Kabul, Afghanistan. He is married and has four children. He has a shop selling fresh fruit and vegetables and has been involved in this business for more than five years. He works hard to earn money to meet his family’s requirements. He needs to buy more fruit and vegetables for his shop because he has lots of problems.
 
Humayoon wants to take out a loan to expand his business to earn money and support all his family's needs. He is very glad that he has the chance to progress in his business and life.

Thanks to all lenders, Kiva and AFS in Afghanistan.

loans.use: To buy more fruit and vegetables for his shop

loans.name: James

texts.en:
James is a 76-year-old carpenter who has 36 years' experience in his business. He makes furniture and has employed one person. He is married and has four children: this is why he strives in his business so that he can support his family.

He is a member of Faulu Kenya under a group of entrepreneurs. With this group, he saves his money and is able to get a loan because the group members guarantee each other's loans. He has requested a loan of 50,000 KES to buy timber for making furniture, spare parts for his machines and money to pay wages for his workers. He hopes to start selling furniture wholesale in the future. He intends to employ more people after he expands his business.

loans.use: To buy timber, machine spare parts and to pay his workers' wages

loans.name: Wilson

texts.en: K. Wilson is a permanent resident of the Kafujo cell Katojo, Bubaare, Kashari Mbarara district. He is 50 years of age, has a poultry business and is a married man with three children. He is using the loan to purchase more poultry chicks, feed, medications, etc. in order to expand his business. He is a hard-working businessman whose dream is to prosper.

loans.use: To purchase more poultry chicks, feed, medications, etc.

loans.name: Heng

texts.en:
Mrs. Heng A., 32, was a grocery seller when she was single, but now she is married to Mr. Roeun, 31, who is a construction laborer for a small firm. They are both good parents of two kids who are enrolled in school.

Recently Heng A. sold nearly all her grocery items.  She hopes to supply more items for her store but she does not have enough capital, so Heng A. is applying for a $400 loan in order to buy a variety of items that she sold such as cooking ingredients, sweets, snacks, soft drinks, cane goods, and plastic goods.

loans.use: To buy cooking ingredients, sweets, snacks, and soft drinks.

loans.name: Ma. Bella

texts.en: Ma. Bella L. is from the town of Talibon. She is 43 years old, married and has 4 school-aged children. To make a living, Ma. Bella owns and operates a general store, selling both food and daily use products in the local community. Ma. Bella has been engaged in her business for over 5 years now. In 2005, Ma. Bella joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Ma. Bella has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. She is requesting a new loan of 30,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to buy materials for a water tank. About CEVI: Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly in recent years. Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines. In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring. CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but, additionally, savings, insurance, and training which are provided through regular cluster group meetings. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell.

loans.name: Tamana Dil Jan Group

texts.en:
Bibi J. is the daughter of M. D. and is the leader of Tamana Dil J. group. She lives in Kabul, Afghanistan. She is 43 and married. There are 7 members in her house and all of them benefit from the income her eldest son Saboor gets from selling different kinds of fruits and vegetables in his fresh fruits and vegetables shop.

Saboor would like to expand his business and buy more fruits and vegetables for his shop, especially those items which are not available and for which there is a lot of demand in the market, so his mother (Bibi J.) has requested a loan for him.

She would like to say that Kiva is an effective loans process in Afghanistan.

loans.use: To buy more fruits and vegetables for shop

loans.name: Julieta

texts.en:
Julieta L., aged 30, is from the town of Talibon. She is married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, she owns and operates a general store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling both food and daily use products in the local community.

In 2005, Julieta joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI. Julieta is requesting a new loan of 25000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the seventh loan she has taken out from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to expand her business.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Bi

texts.en:
Mr. Bi T. stands alongside the river fishing where he can catch many kilos of fish each day. He sells the fish to middle traders who then take it to retail at the market. By doing this, he has the ability to feed his family members. Also, Mr. Bi T. relies on the income from his wife’s commerce, in which she sells a few groceries from home.

As Mr. Bi T. has seven children, the income is sometimes not adequate to serve their needs. He has therefore requested a loan for capital to begin investing in a vegetable business. With any remaining money from the loan, he will buy more groceries for his wife to sell.

loans.use: To invest in a vegetable business and to buy more groceries to sell

loans.name: Kyamwasha Bakyara Kwebisaho, Ntungamo Group

texts.en:
The hard work and creative nature of R. Donosio has seen him operate a thriving business handling local brew, commonly referred to as “waragi” here in Uganda. The married father of eleven children has been running this business for the last thirty-five years in Kyamwasha, Ntungamo district.

Donosio’s current setback is having insufficient capital to purchase the materials used, including bananas whose prices have hiked, thus leaving the brewing behind. Therefore, this loan will help him to revive his business in terms of expansion and also be able to earn more revenue.

loans.use: To purchase more materials, like bananas, for making local brew

loans.name: Marites

texts.en:
Marites O. is from the town of Talibon. She is 40 years old, married and has children who go to school. To make a living, Marites owns and operates  a fishing business. She makes "panggals", fish baskets which her husband uses to catch fish. She also sells these to other fishermen. She has been engaged in this business for almost two years now.

In 2008, Marites joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI. Marites is requesting a new loan of 12000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business.She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay her children's tuition fees. 

About CEVI:

Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over recent years. Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines. In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring. CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but additionally savings, insurance and training which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Sendrida

texts.en: M. Sendrida is a hard-working businesswoman and resident of Kakoba Central Cell, Kakoba Division, Mbarara Municipality. She is married and blessed with three children. She runs a retail shop and has been in her business for over five years. She is using the loan to purchase retail shop items such as salt, soap, flour, rice, sugar, etc. Her future hope is to expand her business.

loans.use: To purchase retail shop items such as salt, soap, flour, rice, sugar, etc.

loans.name: Dzhumataeva's Group

texts.en:
Dzhumataeva T. is the leader of the group and a resident of Karabalta. T. is 51 years old and a widow. She has raised five children: three sons and two daughters. All the children except the youngest son are married and live separately with their families. Her son always helps her with housework. T. has been engaged in cattle breeding activity for 25 years. The initial amount of her business activity was 16000 soms ($343.27). She took out a loan to buy a cow and now makes 8200 soms ($175.96) per month. Thanks to this profit, T. could buy a house and pay for her sons to marry. Now, she wants to take out a loan to purchase fuel and seeds needed for farming. In future, she plans to pay for her younger son to marry.

Ushunbaeva A. is the treasurer of the group. She's 40 years old and is married with a 22-year-old daughter and a 20-year-old son both of whom are students. A.'s husband always helps her with housework.  A. and her husband are engaged in cattle breeding and milk sales. Twenty years ago, they acquired livestock through inheritance so thanks to this, they earn 8200 soms ($175.96) per month and could pay for their children's education. A. wants to take out a loan to purchase fuel and seed potatoes. In future, they wish to buy a car.

Algozhoev R. is 42 years old and is married. He has a daughter and a son. His daughter is eight and studies at school while his son is preschool age. R. and his wife have been engaged in cattle breeding for 20 years. The initial amount of their activity was 18000 soms ($386.26), and from this money they bought a cow. As a result they make 9000 soms ($193.13) per month. They also bought home furniture and built a shed. So, now R. wants to take out a loan to buy fuel which is needed for the sowing process. In future, he plans to buy a car.

Djumalieva A. is 38 years old, is married and has raised three daughters. The older daughter is married, the others study at school. When the children have free time, they help A. with housework. A.'s husband works as a tractor driver. He's also engaged in cattle breeding. Twenty years ago, having an initial amount of 16000 soms, they bought a cow. So their monthly income is 14800 soms ($317.60). Thanks to this, they bought a vehicle and paid for their daughter to be married.  Now they need a loan to purchase fuel and seed potatoes.

Isakova C. is 53 years old and is married. She has three sons and a daughter. The older son is married and lives separately with his family, the second son works as a tractor driver and the younger one helps C. at home. The daughter is 19 years old and works in Bishkek. C. and her husband are engaged in cattle breeding. Several years ago they took out a loan of 18000 soms ($386.26) with which they bought a cow. As a result, they make 5900 soms ($126.60) per month. So, now C. wants to take out a loan to buy fuel, which is needed for farming. In future, she plans to build a house, to purchase a vehicle and to pay for her sons to marry. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan.

Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan which delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: To purchase fuel and seeds needed for farming

loans.name: Sosan Yaqoobi Group

texts.en:
Ziba is the daughter of M. H. and the leader of the Sosan Yaqoobi group. She lives in Kabul, Afghanistan, and is 75 years old. She is married and has six children, three daughters and three sons. She has a needlework business and works in her own home. Ziba has been involved in this business for more than three years. Now she would like to expand her business and buy necessary items such as a frame, etc. for her needlework business.

Therefore, she has requested a loan for this purpose. She is very happy with this loan process in Afghanistan.

loans.use: To buy necessary items such as a frame, etc. for her needlework business

loans.name: Fayzullo

texts.ru: Алиев Файзулло проживает в городе Куляб. Возраст, 50 лет. Женат, имеет 4 детей. Образование - среднее. Более 7 лет занимается животноводством. Разводит скот у себя дома. Этот бизнес приносит ему доход. Кредит берет для закупа крупно - рогатого скота, чтобы увеличить их количество.
texts.en:
Fayzullo A. lives in the city of Kulob. He is 50 years old, married and has 4 children. He has a secondary education. Fayzullo has been involved in animal husbandry for over 7 years. He breeds livestock at home. This business earns him an income. He is requesting the loan for the purchase of cattle in order to increase the livestock quantity.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of cattle

loans.name: Abdul

texts.en: Mr. Abdul N. L. is a 50-year-old man residing in Kitobero Cell, Nyamitanga Division, Mbarara Municipality. He has a grocery shop. There are five members in his family. He is using the loan to boost his business by increasing his stock through purchasing more grocery items such as sugar, books and reams of paper, cooking oil, bread, drinks, etc. for sale. His future hope is to enlarge his business.

loans.use: To purchase grocery items for sale

loans.name: James

texts.en: James is 41 years old, married and has four children. In the past 16 years, he has been operating a butcher shop. He also has rental houses from which he earns more income to support his family. He is a new member of Faulu Kenya and belongs to a group in Faulu Kenya whose main aim is to save money, share business ideas and guarantee each other's loans. He has requested a loan of 50,000 KES to buy a weighing machine, fridge and a water tank. This will be his first loan and he hopes that it will help him to improve his business. He hopes to have a well-established business.

loans.use: To purchase a weighing machine, fridge and water tank

loans.name: Bolormaa

texts.en: Bolormaa is 43 years old and lives with her husband and three children in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. She and her family live together in a rental house. Her 21-year-old son and 18-year-old daughter attend a university. Her younger daughter is 11 years old and attends a local secondary school. Currently, Bolormaa operates a women's clothing sales business. She operates a retail business. She purchases a variety of products from Ereen, a Chinese border city, and resells them for a profit. She started her business in 2003 with working capital of 600,000 tugrugs (~ 146 USD) and has expanded her business with a loyal customer base. Bolor is a very hardworking person and likes to say “Nothing is impossible”. Her dream is to purchase an apartment. She is requesting a loan to increase her working capital.

loans.use: To increase her working capital

loans.name: United We Stand Group

texts.en:
Fallah T. is the leader of a group of five borrowers called United We Stand.  He is 56 years old, married and has three children who range in age from 20 to 35. He never had the opportunity to attend school due to poverty. For 20 years, he has been selling building materials at the Waterside Market in Monrovia, Liberia. He sells in a friendly manner which keeps customers returning.  

He plans to use his 8,000 Liberian dollar portion of this 58,000 Liberian dollar group loan to buy more building materials. His goal is to grow his business and to continue to support his children so that they can have a better future.

In the photo that accompanies this profile, Fallah is the one holding the sign.

loans.use: To buy more building materials

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Increasing goods turnover

loans.name: Kavira

texts.fr:
Kavira S.  est  entrepreneur, vendeuse des poissons Tilapia, cliente au 14e cycle, âgée de 27 ans, mariée, mère de 2 enfants respectivement âgés de 9 ans et 4 ans.  Tous étudient, le fils ainé fait la 3e année primaire et le second fait l’école gardienne. 
Son mari est aussi vendeur des poissons, elle s’entraide avec son mari dans ce business de vente des poissons Tilapia.
Madame Kavira S. a commencé son petit commerce  avec  son fonds propre. Elle fut petite marchande, revendeuse des poissons  sans capital, détaillante, elle spéculait avec les marchandises (poissons) de ses amis et connaissances qui étaient déjà grossistes. Elle prenait les poissons à crédit et les revendre pour payer après l’opération. C’était une façon de lui initier à l’auto prise en charge. Cependant  les petits bénéfices cumulés de son business informel lui a permis de se constituer un capital de 50$ pour démarrage. Et un peu après, elle a profité le 1er crédit de l'IMF Hekima.
Au paravent, quand  madame Kavira S.  avait un petit fond de rotation, elle vendait les poissons du lac Virunga (en RD Congo) anciennement appelé lac Edouard, lac Idi Amine en provenance de la pecherie de vitshumbi et Nyakakoma, deux villages situés respectivement à 150 km de la ville de Goma. Plus tard, lorsqu’elle se vit  son capital  augmente en volume, immediatement elle a préféré  changer l’axe d’approvisionnement pour réaliser plus des profits, elle vend des poissons Tilapia provenant de lac Victoria de l’Ouganda. La spécificité de ces poissons, ils sont plus gros par rapport aux poissons de lac Edouard. Il y a 8 ans qu’elle exerce cette activité de vente des poissons. Elle s’installe sur le lieu public, route Katindo, entrée du camp Militaire.
Avec  le crédit  de  l’IMF Hekima, Kavira S. souhaite augmenter son chiffre d’affaire en achetant  600 kg des poissons  frais appelés « gros tilapia».
Madame Kavira S., explique le défi majeur de son activité est lié à la pourriture de poisson, surtout lorsque le glace (glacier) est finiou transformé en liquide pour garder les poissons en état frais. En outre le transport de leur marchandise de l’Ouganda-kampala vers la RD Congo pose un problème d’autant plus qu’il n’y a pas assez des véhicules transporteurs impliqués dans ce secteur de transport poisson. Par exemple à ce jour, madame Kavira S. n’a pas des marchandises parce que il n'y a que’un seul véhicule qui fait ce trafic routier transfrontalier, et seulement 3 ou 4 operateurs ougandais qui font ce transport avec leurs véhicules jusqu'au frontière entre l'Ouganda et le RD Congo.
Dans l’avenir, elle ambitionne louer, elle seule un camion de poissons Tilapia sans se faire liguer avec d’autres associés de sa corporation.  Elle reste très optimiste en soulignant qu’un jour elle sera grand fournisseur des poissons tilapia dans la ville de Goma. Dans le futur, elle souhaiterait  acheter sa propre parcelle et y construire une maison, étant donné qu’elle est encore locataire de maison. 
Madame Kavira S. remercie l’IMF Hekima pour  les crédits  qu’elle reçoit sans aucune garantie matérielle car grâce à ces crédits, elle parvient à subvenir aux besoins de ses enfants.
texts.en:
Kavira S. is an entrepreneur, a seller of tilapia fish.  She is a 14th cycle client, 27 years old, married, and the mother of two children, aged 9 and 4.  Both are in school.  Her son, the eldest, is in the third grade, and the other is in kindergarten.  Kavira's husband is also a fish seller.  She and her husband help each other in this business selling tilapia.  She started her small business with her own funds.  Kavira was once a small-scale merchant, a fish seller without working capital, a retailer.  She used to speculate with goods (fish) belonging to her friends and acquaintances who were already wholesale merchants.  She got the fish on credit and resold it, paying afterward.  This was a way for her to become familiar with self-sufficiency.  Meanwhile, the small profits from her informal business accumulated and enabled her to build up $50 in capital to start off.  A year later, she availed herself of the first loan with the micro-finance institution Hekima.  In the past, when Kavira had a small revolving fund, she used to sell fish from Lake Virunga (in the Democratic Republic of the Congo) formerly called Lake Edouard, Lake Edi Amine from the fishery of Vitshumbi and Nyakakoma, two villages located 150 km from the city of Goma.  Later, when she saw her capital increase in volume, she immediately favored changing her supply source in order to make more profit.  She sells tilapia from Lake Victoria in Uganda.  These fish are specifically bigger compared to the fish from Lake Edouard.  She has been in this business selling fish for eight years.  She situated herself in the public space on Katindo Road, at the entrance to the military camp.  With the Hekima loan, Kavira wishes to increase her sales by buying 600 kg of fresh fish called gros tilapia.  Kavira explains that the major challenge in her business is related to fish spoiling, especially when the ice has turned liquid in the cooler for keeping the fish fresh.  Furthermore, the transport of Uganda-Kampala merchandise toward the Democratic Republic of the Congo poses a problem, as much as there are not enough transport vehicles involved in this sector for transporting fish.  For example, today, Kavira has no merchandise because there was not one vehicle running the trans-border trade in the DRC, and only three or four economic Ugandan operators using their vehicles to take fish as far as the border.  In the future, Kavira has the ambition to lease, on her own, a tilapia truck without joining forces with other companies in her corporation.  She remains very optimistic, emphasizing that, one day, she will be a major supplier of tilapia in her city of Goma.  For the future, she wishes to buy her own plot of land and to build house on it, since she is still renting a house.  Kavira thanks Hekima for the loans she receives without the need for any collateral at all because, thanks to these loans, she is managing to meet the needs of her children. 

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: 600 kg of fish

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Rosemary

texts.en: Rosemary is 52 years old and widowed. She has been selling chickens for 10 years. She is also involved in a construction business.  She is in the Mafuno self-help group in Faulu Kenya where she saves her money on a weekly basis. During the meetings, she also shares business ideas with fellow businessmen and women. Being in this group, she has been guaranteed a loan of 60,000 KES by the group members. With this loan, she plans to buy more chicks and chickens. She hopes that someday she will sell her chicks wholesale.

loans.use: To buy more chicks and chickens

loans.name: Sieng

texts.en: Sieng V. is 28 years old, married, and the mother of a young child who attends the local public school. She stays at home to manage the family housework and also sells some fruit to villagers for extra income. Sieng is married to 40-year-old Bunny, who helps support the family by running a motor taxi. Sieng V. will be using her loan to purchase a trailer to attach to the existing motorcycle, so her husband will be able to pick up more passengers.

loans.use: To purchase a trailer to attach to existing motorcycle

loans.name: Tiapokel Ole

texts.en:
Tiapokel Ole S. is 43 years old, married to Leitato S., and a father of six school-going children. He has been a maize farmer for the last 12 years.
Tiapokel learned about Kiva partner, KADET, from other members in a group already registered with KADET in his area of residence. This will be his first loan, which he is planning to spend on preparing his land for planting maize. Maize has been doing well in his area due to good climatic conditions. He hopes to use the profit from the proceeds of this loan to expand his farming activity from small-scale to commercial farming.
Tiapokel's dream is be involved in large-scale farming and start dairy farming. He is a hardworking man who is determined to achieve his goals.

loans.use: To prepare the land for planting maize

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To purchase more stock for his business

loans.name: John

texts.en: John is a 56-year-old married man with five children. He has ten years' experience in dairy farming and sells animal products such as meat and milk. John also does carpentry to earn a living. He joined Kiva partner, Faulu Kenya, under a group called Better Ventures Self-Help Group. He is a very active member of the group and attends its weekly meetings regularly. John has also been saving his money with the group. He uses his savings to boost the business. Due to his commitment in paying his loans, he has been allowed to service another loan of 60,000 KES. With this loan, he plans to buy a dairy cow and animal feed. He hopes to become a large-scale farmer in the future.

loans.use: To buy a dairy cow and animal feed

loans.name: Aisha

texts.en: Z. Aisha is a prominent businesswoman who has a restaurant business in the bus park of Mbarara town. She is using her loan to purchase a variety of foodstuffs for her business to attract more customers. She is a married woman who is blessed with two children, who go to school. Her hope is to operate a large and more profitable restaurant than the small one she owns currently.

loans.use: To purchase a variety of foodstuffs for her restaurant

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase of cement

loans.name: Joseph

texts.en:
Joseph is 50 years old and lives in Kiambu. Together with his wife, he has been selling milk since 1996. The couple works hard to provide a better standard of living for the family.
Joseph is a member of a group whose members receive loans from Kiva partner, Faulu Kenya. He attends the weekly meetings and pays his loans well. So far, his business has been running well but he has insufficient storage facilities. He has therefore requested a loan of 80,000 KES from Faulu Kenya to buy a freezer. He hopes to attract more customers so that he can earn more income to improve his standard of living.

loans.use: To buy a freezer

loans.name: Noeun

texts.en: Mrs. Nouen S. became a fruit seller when she was single, but she is now married with three young children, all of whom are students and dependent upon their parents' income. Nouen sells fruits that she orders in bulk from her wholesale supplier, operating her business inside the market, generating substantial income for her family. Her husband fishes for a profit but now requires more equipment, so Nouen is requesting a loan of $1000 to make the necessary purchases.

loans.use: To purchase fishing equipment for her husband's business

loans.name: Joanes

texts.en: Joanes, 36 years old and married with four children who go to school, has provided tailoring and laundry services for the past seven years and has two employees.  Since he joined Faulu Kenya, he has grown his business from retail into wholesale.  While he was previously living in a slum, he has since moved out and into a permanent house, due mainly to the fact that he used two previous loans to boost his business, thereby increasing his profits.  Joanes is now requesting a loan of Kes.40,000 from Faulu Kenya to buy more fabric for making clothes and an iron box.  He hopes to provide quality education for his children in the future.

loans.use: To buy fabric and an iron box

loans.name: Huth

texts.en: Huth H. is a 42-year-old village woman wH. has worked as a fish catcher since she was single. She goes with her husband to fish along the river. When she is done fishing, she sells the fish, which allows her to earn approximately $4 a day. The humble couple has six children:  two are married and the other four are single. As fishing season approaches, the river is full of fish but the family lacks fishing equipment. Huth H. is applying for a loan to purchase additional fishing supplies to support her business activities.

loans.use: To purchase additional fishing equipment in order to support her business activities.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To purchase more jeans to sell

loans.name: Together As One Group

texts.en:
Paul D. is the leader of a group of 5 borrowers called Together As One. He is 44 years old and married, with 3 children who range in age from 4 to 19 years old. Paul is a high-school graduate, but could not continue his education to college due to financial problems.

For 18 years, Paul has been selling wristwatches and radios at the Red Light market in Paynesville, Liberia. Paul started selling with 2,500 Liberian Dollars in working capital and now has about 40,000 Liberian Dollars in working capital.  Paul has a nice manner of approaching his customers in order to keep them returning. He plans to use his 16,000 Liberian Dollar-portion of this group loan to purchase more wristwatches and radios.

Paul's goal and dream is to expand his business to a store and improve the living condition of his family through education.
 In the photo that accompanies this profile, Paul is holding the sign.

loans.use: To purchase more wristwatches and radios.

loans.name: Seydou

texts.fr:
Monsieur Seydou D. est un homme marié de 34 ans et père de 2 enfants qui vit avec sa femme et ses enfants dans le quartier Hérémakono Nord de la ville de Bougouni (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Seydou n’ a pas fréquenté le système scolaire, mais suivait plutôt  leurs animaux c’est à dire faisait  l’activité du berger pour son père au village.
Afin de s'inserrer  dans le tissu économique, il décida de quitter le village pour la ville de Bougouni  dans le dessein d’apprendre le commerce d’articles divers au niveau d’une  boutique.
 Avec 4 années d'expériences, il maîtrise cette activité qu’il a appris auprès de son frère. Il est très sollicité et apprécié à Bougouni.
 Dans le souci de renforcer son commerce, Monsieur Seydou D. intégra le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso, avec qui il est à son deuxième prêt individuel et le précédent prêt a été correctement remboursé.
Seydou D. compte acheter, une importante quantité d’articles divers tels les anti-moustiques,  des sachets de lait en poudre, des baumes ‘’Temple of Heaven’’, des bics, des piles, du thé, de l’eau de javel, des cubes maggi etc.
Il s’approvisionne à Bougouni et à Bamako (capitale de la république du Mali) auprès des grossistes et effectue sa vente à une clientèle diverse et variée, au comptant, en détail et crédit.
Avec ce prêt, Monsieur Seydou D. compte réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 65 000 FCFA.
 Avec ce bénéfice il envisage toujours agrandir sa boutique.
texts.en:
Mr. Seydou D. is a 34-year-old man, married, and the father of two children.  He lives with this wife and children in the Hérémakono Nord district of the city of Bougouni (3rd administrative region of the Republic of Mali).  He did not attend school but rather followed their animals, that is, he worked as a shepherd for his father in the village.  In order to become part of the economic fabric, he decided to leave his village for the city of Bougouni with plans to learn about commerce in a variety of shop goods.  With four years of experience, he is mastering this business, which he learned from his father.  He is much in demand and highly appreciated in Bougouni. Concerned about bolstering his business, Seydou joined the Soro Yiriwaso loan program and is now on his second individual loan.  The preceding one was properly repaid.  He intends to buy a major quantity of various goods, such as anti-mosquito products, pouches of powdered milk, Temple of Heaven balms, ink pens, batteries, tea, bleach, Maggi bouillon cubes, etc.  He gets his supplies in Bougouni and in Bamako (capital of Mali) from wholesalers.  Accepting cash or credit, he makes his sales to a diverse and varied customer base.  With this loan, Seydou plans on making a monthly profit of 65,000 francs CFA that he still envisions using to expand his shop.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying a variety of good for his store

loans.name: The Power Of God Group

texts.en:
Annie N. is the leader of a group of 5 borrowers called The Power Of God. She is 51 years old and married, with 2 children who are 22 and 26 years old. Annie did not have the opportunity to go to school.

For 20 years she has been selling lappas ( (fabrics used by African women to wrap around their body or made into clothing) on a table at the Red Light market in Paynesville, Liberia. Annie started selling with 1,500 Liberian Dollars in worK. capital and now has about 25,000 Liberian Dollars in worK. capital.  Annie encourages her customers with good words in order to keep them returning. She plans to use her 9,000 Liberian Dollar-portion of this  group loan to purchase more lappas.


Her goal and dream is to expand her business to a bigger table and improve the living condition of her family.

In the photo that accompanies this profile, Abel is holding the sign. And Musu is inset at the lower right because she was absent during interview.

loans.use: To purchase more lappas.

loans.name: Linda

texts.en: Linda is 29 years old and married, with one child.  She operates Linda's Cafe while her husband sells clothes.  In addition, she rents houses.  She has run the cafe for three years and hopes to expand it. She uses her income to pay wages to her three employees and to support her family.  She joined Faulu Kenya after being introduced by a friend to a group called Millennium so that she could easily access loans.  She has requested her first loan of KES 50,000 to enlarge her cafeteria and buy food supplies.

loans.use: To enlarge the cafeteria and buy food supplies

loans.name: United Women Group

texts.en:
Massa O. is the leader of a group of five borrowers called United Women. She is 31 years old, married, and has three children who range from one to eleven years of age. Massa could not continue her education through high school.
For the last ten years, Massa has been selling cooked food at the Redlight market in Paynesville, Liberia. She started selling with funds given to her by her husband, but she lacks assistance in her business operation. Massa provides good service to her customers in order to keep them returning. She plans to use her 12,000 LRD portion of this 37,000 LRD group loan to purchase more ingredients and utensils for cooking. Her goal and dream is to advance and increase her business size to a shop.
In the photo that accompanies this profile, Massa is holding the sign. Joe is inset lower right.

loans.use: To purchase more ingredients and utensils for cooking

loans.name: Leilla

texts.en:
Leilla S. is 40 years old, widowed, and has two children who go to school. She is currently in the business of selling bread and charcoal at the market, and is requesting a loan to stock more bags of charcoal. With the extra profits from her loan, Leilla hopes to build up a restaurant.

About BRAC
BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted at returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To stock more bags of charcoal

loans.name: Nyoka

texts.en:
Nyoka J. is 38 years old, married to an engineer, and has five children who all go to school. She is currently in the business of selling green vegetables, such as okra, dodo (leafy greens of the amaranth plant), etc., and is requesting a loan to stock tomatoes and dried fish to sell. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to expand her business by stocking more dried fish and also build a shop.

About BRAC
BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted at returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To stock tomatoes and dried fish to sell

loans.name: Poni

texts.en:
Poni J. is 39 years old, widowed, and has three children who go to school. She is currently in the business of selling simsim (sesame seed), tomatoes, etc. and is requesting a loan to stock bags of cowpeas, pulses and cassava flour. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to build up a big shop.

About BRAC
BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted at returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To stock bags of cowpeas, pulses and cassava flour to sell

loans.name: Stanley

texts.en: Stanley is 45 years old and married with four children. He has been running N. shoe shop for two years. He joined the Dafulos group in Kiva partner, Faulu Kenya, in order to access working capital. When he got his first loan from Faulu Kenya, he used it as capital to start his shoe business. He has been able to construct a house and rental houses on his piece of land. He hopes to complete the houses so that he can earn more income to educate his children. Stanley has requested a loan of 40,000 KES to add to his stock of shoes and buy grill windows for fixing on his house.

loans.use: To buy shoes plus grill windows for his house

loans.name: Togetherness Group

texts.en:
Joe K. is the leader of a group of five borrowers called Togetherness. He is 47 years old, married, and has four children aged from 7 to 27 years old. He was only able to attend school through 12th grade due to poverty. He cares for one sibling.
For four years, Joe has been selling soft drinks, soap and cosmetics on Front Street, Monrovia, Liberia. He sells in a friendly manner, which keeps customers returning. He plans to use his 24,000 LRD portion of this 72,000 LRD group loan to buy more soft drinks, soap and cosmetics. His goal is to grow his business and continue to support his children so that they can have a better future.
In the photo that accompanies this profile, Joe is the one holding the sign.

loans.use: To buy more soft drinks, soap and cosmetics

loans.name: Ever

texts.en:
Ever Peter is currently in the business of selling maize flour and rice and is requesting a loan to stock cassava flour and more bags of rice to sell. Ever is 38 years old and is married, with a husband that is a policeman. She has 5 children, and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house for rent.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights, and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations.
